This is the most dangerous disease where oily spots appear on the fruit and later crack open. Immediately cut and burn all infected branches and fruits to stop the spread. After pruning, apply Bordeaux paste on cut ends. Spray a mixture of Streptocycline (0.5 gram) and Copper Oxychloride (2.5 grams) per liter of water. During the rainy season, repeat the spray every 10-15 days and keep the orchard floor very clean.

Small, dark brown spots appear on the fruit skin, which later become hard and sunken. Prune and destroy dried twigs and infected fruits. Spray Carbendazim @ 1 gram per liter or Propiconazole @ 1 ml per liter during the fruit development stage. If the weather is cloudy and humid, spray Mancozeb @ 2 grams per liter to protect the healthy fruits.

The fruit looks healthy from the outside, but the inside turns black and rotten with a foul smell. This fungus enters through the flower. To prevent this, spray Mancozeb @ 2 grams per liter or Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter during the flowering stage. Ensure the tree gets enough Boron and Calcium so the flower end does not crack and let the fungus in.

Fruits crack open, usually due to irregular watering or Boron deficiency. Maintain constant soil moisture by watering regularly; do not let the soil get too dry and then flood it. Spray Borax or Solubor @ 2 grams per liter when the fruits are lemon-sized. Mulching the soil with dry grass helps keep moisture levels steady and prevents cracking.

A black or white hard patch forms on the side of the fruit facing the sun, damaging the quality. Protect the developing fruits by covering them with paper bags or dry grass. Maintain a good leaf canopy by providing balanced nutrition so the leaves naturally shade the fruits. In extreme heat, spray Kaolin clay (50 grams per liter) to create a white protective layer on the fruits.

The butterfly lays eggs on the flower/fruit, and the caterpillar bores inside, causing rot and bad smell. Cover the fruits with butter paper bags or polymer bags when they are the size of a lemon. Remove and destroy any fruits with holes immediately. Spray Neem Oil @ 3 ml per liter or Spinosad @ 0.3 ml per liter when the fruits are small to keep the pest away.

Black necrotic spots cover the fruit surface, reducing its market value. This usually happens in warm, humid weather. Clean the orchard by removing weeds and fallen leaves. Spray Thiophanate Methyl @ 1 gram per liter or Chlorothalonil @ 2 grams per liter. Repeat the spray after 15 days if the spots continue to appear.

Small reddish-brown spots appear, often starting near the crown (calyx) of the fruit, eventually causing rot. Spray Mancozeb @ 2.5 grams per liter or Tebuconazole @ 1 ml per liter during fruit development. Improve air circulation in the orchard by pruning extra branches so humidity does not build up around the fruits.

This disease causes dark, sunken spots on the fruit, which eventually harden or rot. To control it, prune the tree to remove dead twigs and overcrowded branches. Spray Carbendazim @ 1 gram per liter or Mancozeb @ 2 grams per liter when the fruits are setting. Ensure the orchard is clean and destroy any fallen, rotting fruits immediately to prevent the fungus from spreading to healthy trees.

A black, powdery layer covers the fruit, reducing its market price. This is caused by sticky honeydew from insects like scale insects and mealybugs. To fix this, spray a Starch solution (boil 1 kg Maida in 5 liters of water, cool, and dilute in 20 liters) on the fruits; as it dries, the mold peels off. You must also control the insects by spraying Neem Oil @ 5 ml per liter or Dimethoate @ 2 ml per liter.

The branches become flat and twisted, and the fruits produced on them are tiny, clustered, and useless. This is a viral or genetic disorder. The only effective treatment is to cut and remove the flattened branches immediately and apply Bordeaux paste on the cut ends. Do not use grafts or bud sticks from trees that have this problem. Maintain good nutrition to keep the tree strong.

Many young fruits turn yellow and drop off before maturing due to temperature changes or water stress. To stop this, spray NAA (Planofix) @ 4 ml in 18 liters of water twice: once during flowering and again when fruits are pea-sized. Alternatively, spray Gibberellic Acid (GA3) @ 50 ppm. Ensure regular watering during the summer months to keep the soil moisture constant.

The larvae bore into flower buds and young fruits, causing them to dry up and fall with a hole visible. Clean the orchard floor by removing fallen buds and fruits. Install light traps to catch the moths. Spray Quinalphos @ 2 ml per liter or Profenofos @ 1 ml per liter during the bud and flowering stage. Avoid spraying chemicals when the fruit is close to harvest.

This is a serious pest where a tiny worm enters the fruit and eats the seed inside, making the fruit rot from within. The entry hole heals, so the fruit looks fine outside but is bad inside. Collect and burn all fallen fruits. Spray Deltamethrin @ 1 ml per liter or Neem Oil @ 5 ml per liter when fruits are marble-sized to prevent the pest from entering.

Small, pinkish to reddish-brown spots appear on the fruit skin, which may join together to form large patches. Prune the canopy to allow sunlight to reach the inner branches. Spray Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter or Thiophanate Methyl @ 1 gram per liter during fruit development. Repeat the spray after 20 days if the weather remains humid.

This disease spreads in cool, humid weather and thick crop growth. Keep good air movement by avoiding overcrowding and removing infected fruits and old leaves. Do not irrigate late in the evening. If needed, spray Carbendazim or Hexaconazole @ 1 g per liter of water. Harvest fruits on time and keep them dry during storage to reduce mold development.

This disease occurs when fruits touch wet soil. Use mulching with straw or plastic to keep fruits off the ground. Improve drainage and avoid water stagnation. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb @ 2 g per liter after heavy rains. Remove and destroy infected fruits immediately, as they give bitter taste and spread infection in the field.

Collect and destroy infected fruits regularly to stop spread. Avoid overhead irrigation, especially during flowering and fruiting. Spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb @ 2 g per liter at early fruit stage and repeat if needed. Keep the field clean and rotate crops every season to reduce fungus buildup in soil.

This disease looks like white powder on fruits and leaves and spreads in dry weather. Spray Wettable Sulphur @ 2 g per liter or Hexaconazole @ 1 ml per liter. Remove heavily infected plant parts. Ensure proper spacing between plants for air movement. Balanced fertilizer use helps fruits ripen properly and reduces disease severity.

This disease mainly spreads after harvest through wounds on fruits. Handle fruits carefully during harvesting and transport to avoid injuries. Remove damaged fruits immediately. Keep storage areas clean and dry. Dip harvested fruits in hot water (48–50°C for 2–3 minutes) or spray Carbendazim @ 1 g per liter to reduce rot during storage.

This rot starts near the fruit cap, so always harvest fruits carefully without pulling the green cap. Remove and destroy infected fruits from the field. Avoid overhead watering during fruiting and keep good air circulation. Spray Carbendazim or Thiophanate-methyl @ 1 g per liter at early fruit stage. Clean field sanitation and timely harvest greatly reduce this disease.

Collect and destroy infected fruits and fallen plant waste regularly. Avoid water splashing on fruits during irrigation. Spray Mancozeb @ 2 g per liter or Chlorothalonil at fruit development stage. Maintain proper plant spacing and apply balanced fertilizer, especially potassium. Good air flow and clean field conditions help prevent further spread and keep fruits market-ready.

This disease spreads during humid weather. Remove affected fruits immediately to stop spread. Avoid dense planting and improve air circulation. Spray Carbendazim or Propiconazole @ 1 g per liter at early symptom stage. Use clean planting material and avoid wetting fruits while watering. Proper drainage and timely spray help fruits remain healthy and smooth.

This rot develops very fast after harvest, especially on injured fruits. Harvest carefully to avoid cuts and bruises. Remove damaged fruits immediately. Keep harvested fruits in a cool, dry place. Dip fruits in hot water at 48–50°C for 2–3 minutes or spray Carbendazim @ 1 g per liter to reduce post-harvest losses.

This disease spreads very fast in hot, humid weather. Remove and destroy infected fruits immediately to stop spread. Avoid overcrowding and ensure good air flow between plants. Do not irrigate late evening. Spray Carbendazim or Mancozeb @ 2 g per liter at early symptoms. Keep the field clean and well-drained to reduce humidity and fungal growth.

Sunscald happens due to strong sunlight, not germs. Protect fruits by maintaining good leaf cover; avoid excessive pruning. Use straw mulch or shade nets to reduce heat stress. Water the field regularly to avoid moisture stress. Balanced fertilizer application helps plants maintain healthy foliage, which naturally shields fruits from direct sun damage.

Collect and destroy mummified fruits from plants and soil, as they spread infection next season. Improve air circulation by proper spacing and pruning. Avoid water splash on fruits. Spray Carbendazim or Propiconazole @ 1 g per liter during flowering and early fruit stage. Good field sanitation is the most effective control method for this disease.

These rots enter through wounds caused by birds, cracks, or rough handling. Control birds using nets and harvest fruits carefully. Remove damaged fruits immediately. Keep storage rooms clean, cool, and dry. Dip fruits in hot water (48–50°C for 2–3 minutes) or spray Carbendazim @ 1 g per liter to reduce post-harvest losses.

This is not a disease. It happens due to lack of calcium and irregular watering. Water the crop regularly and do not allow soil to dry fully or stay flooded. Put mulch like dry leaves or straw to keep moisture. Spray calcium chloride or calcium nitrate on small fruits to help them grow strong and healthy.

This is very common in Karnataka. The worm enters the fruit and eats from inside. Remove and destroy damaged fruits immediately. Use pheromone traps to catch moths early. Grow marigold plants around the field to reduce attack. Spray neem-based spray or biopesticides in the early stage to control worms.

This pest makes tiny holes and damages fruit from inside. Install Tuta pheromone traps and light traps in the field. Remove and burn affected fruits quickly. Do not leave damaged fruits in the field. Rotate crops next season to reduce this pest problem.

Small black or brown sunken spots appear on ripe fruits, especially during rainy weather. Keep fruits off the soil by tying plants to sticks. Harvest fruits as soon as they ripen. Keep the field clean. If rain continues, spray copper-based fungicide to protect fruits.

Dark ring-like spots appear first on old leaves and later on fruits. Remove yellow and infected lower leaves. Give enough space between plants for air movement. Spray Mancozeb or similar fungicide when early symptoms appear on leaves.

Fruits touching wet soil develop round brown spots. Always keep fruits above ground using stakes. Apply straw or plastic mulch to avoid soil contact. Improve drainage and avoid water standing in the field. Raised beds help prevent this problem.

Fruits develop rough brown spots that reduce market value. Avoid sprinkling water on leaves and fruits. Use drip irrigation. Remove affected fruits. Spray copper-based bactericide early to stop further spread during rainy weather.

This virus is common in South India. Infected plants cannot be cured. Remove and destroy the whole plant immediately. Control thrips by fixing blue sticky traps in the field. Spray Neem Oil regularly or Imidacloprid in early stages. Keep the field and borders free from weeds where thrips hide.

This disease appears during cool, cloudy, or misty weather. Spray Mancozeb or Metalaxyl before or at the first sign of disease. Keep enough space between plants so air can flow and leaves dry fast. Avoid watering on leaves, especially in the evening.

Once a plant is infected, it cannot be cured. Remove and destroy infected plants to protect others. Spray copper-based chemicals on healthy plants to reduce spread. Clean knives and tools after use. Always use certified disease-free seeds for the next crop.

This is sunburn, not a disease. It happens in hot weather when fruits are exposed to direct sunlight. Do not remove too many leaves. Allow leaves to shade fruits naturally. During extreme heat, use a light shade net (30%) to protect fruits.

This happens due to sudden heavy watering after dry conditions. Water the crop regularly and evenly. Use mulch to maintain soil moisture. Avoid excess irrigation after rain. Choose crack-resistant varieties if possible. Remove cracked fruits early to avoid rotting.

Fruits become misshapen and scarred, especially in cold North Indian winters. This is not a disease. Avoid planting sensitive varieties during very cold months. Do not apply excess nitrogen fertilizer. Proper planting time is the best solution; sprays will not help.

Fruits look normal but feel light and empty inside. This happens due to poor pollination during very hot or very cold weather. Gently shake plants during daytime to help pollen movement. Avoid spraying chemicals during flowering as they reduce bee activity.

Small white rings appear on fruits in cool and damp weather. Reduce humidity by removing excess leaves so air can pass through plants. In protected cultivation, keep good ventilation. Remove affected fruits. Spray Chlorothalonil only if wet weather continues.

Ripe fruits develop black powdery mold, mainly after rain near harvest. Harvest fruits as soon as they ripen. Avoid fruit cracking and sunburn. Handle fruits carefully during picking so the skin is not damaged.

White or yellow cloudy patches appear on fruit skin, and taste becomes poor. This is caused by stink bugs sucking fruit juice. Keep the field and borders free of weeds. Handpick bugs using gloves. Spray Neem Oil to stop bugs from feeding.

This is the most dangerous disease. Small, water-soaked spots appear on the green husk, which quickly turn black and sunken. The nut inside shrivels, turns black, and rots. To control it, spray Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter or Bordeaux Mixture (1%) starting when the female flowers (catkins) appear. Repeat the spray every 7-10 days if the weather is wet during spring. Avoid overhead sprinklers as water splashing spreads the bacteria.

Circular, sunken, brown spots appear on the green husk. If the infection is severe, the nut drops early or the kernel inside shrivels. The shell may get stained dark. Clean the orchard by burning fallen leaves and nuts in winter, as the fungus lives there. Spray Mancozeb @ 2.5 grams per liter or Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter when the leaves are unfolding and again when the nuts are small.

The larva (worm) bores into the young nut through the blossom end, eating the kernel inside. You will see black waste (frass) at the entry hole. The damaged nuts fall early. Use pheromone traps to catch male moths. Spray Spinosad @ 0.3 ml per liter or Carbaryl @ 2 grams per liter when the moths are flying (usually late spring). Remove and destroy all fallen, infested nuts immediately.

Maggots feed inside the green husk, turning it into a black, soft, mushy liquid. This stains the nut shell a dirty black color and makes the kernel shrivel. Hang yellow sticky traps to catch the flies. Spray a bait mixture (Jaggery/Molasses + Malathion) on the leaves to attract and kill the flies before they lay eggs. This does not damage the nut directly but ruins the quality and price.

The nut looks fine outside, but when cracked, the kernel is covered in green, blue, or black mold. This happens if the hull splits but the nut is not harvested quickly, or if insects damage the shell. Harvest the nuts as soon as 80% of the hulls have split; do not leave them on the tree. Dry the harvested nuts immediately to remove moisture. Controlling sunburn and insect damage also prevents mold.

The side of the green husk facing the hot sun turns yellow or brown and becomes hard. The kernel inside may darken or shrivel. This happens in peak summer. Maintain a healthy canopy of leaves to shade the nuts by providing enough water and fertilizer. In extreme heat, you can whitewash the tree trunks or use overhead misters to cool the orchard, but avoid keeping the nuts wet for too long.

While this affects branches, the main symptom farmers see is the husk and nut drying up suddenly and sticking to the branch (mummies). The outer husk turns greyish-brown. Prune the affected branch well below the wilted part and burn it. Do not shake the tree when harvesting infected nuts, as this spreads fungal spores. Maintain tree health with proper irrigation.

Sunken, circular spots appear on the fruit rind, which turn black during rain, causing the fruit to crack or rot. Clean the field by destroying infected vines and fruits and do not plant watermelon in the same place every year. Spray Carbendazim @ 1 gram per liter or Mancozeb @ 2.5 grams per liter when fruits start forming. Handle fruits carefully to avoid skin damage during harvest.

Dark, water-soaked, oily stains appear on the top surface of the fruit, eventually causing the skin to crack and the fruit to rot inside. This spreads fast in warm, wet weather. Use only certified disease-free seeds. If you see symptoms, spray Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter mixed with Streptocycline (small packet) immediately. Avoid overhead watering (sprinklers) as it splashes bacteria onto the fruit.

The bottom end of the fruit (where the flower was) turns black, leathery, and flat. This is not a fungus but a result of Calcium deficiency and irregular watering. Maintain steady soil moisture by watering regularly; do not let the soil get too dry and then flood it. Spray Calcium Chloride or Calcium Nitrate @ 2 grams per liter when fruits are small (marble-sized) to fix the deficiency.

The part of the fruit touching the wet soil turns brown, soft, and develops mold. To prevent this, do not let fruits sit directly on the soil. Place a piece of wood, stone, or a bed of dry straw (mulch) under each fruit. You can also use plastic mulch sheets before planting. Spraying the soil under the vines with Copper Oxychloride @ 3 grams per liter can help reduce the fungus.

Large white or bleached patches appear on the fruit surface exposed to direct sunlight, making the area weak and prone to rot. Maintain a healthy leaf canopy to shade the fruits by providing proper fertilizers. Cover exposed fruits with dry straw, newspaper caps, or the plant's own leaves during the peak summer heat to protect the skin.

While this attacks stems, it also causes black, wrinkled rot on the fruit, often with gummy oozing. It usually enters through wounds. Clean up crop debris after harvest. Spray Chlorothalonil @ 2 grams per liter or Mancozeb @ 2.5 grams per liter. Ensure good air circulation in the field and avoid injuring the fruit during weeding or turning.

The fruit becomes bumpy, mottled (mixed colors), and deformed, making it hard to sell. This is spread by aphids (greenflies). Remove and destroy weeds around the field where aphids hide. Pull out and bury infected plants immediately. Spray Imidacloprid @ 0.5 ml per liter or Dimethoate @ 2 ml per liter to control the aphids and stop the spread.

The fruit develops soft spots that may turn into white or pink moldy patches, often starting at the stem end. Use resistant varieties if available. Dip the fruit in hot water (55°C) for 2 minutes after harvest to clean the skin. Avoid pulling the fruit from the vine; always cut it with a clipper to leave a smooth stem, preventing the fungus from entering.
